SALESFORCE HELP
DOCS
VISUALFORCE B2B COMMERCE
Manage Configuration Settings

Control most default display, layout, and other user experience decisions for your storefront pages using configuration settings. In CC Admin, you can define global configuration setting values that apply default behavior to all of your storefronts. Tailor individual storefront experiences by overriding specific settings per storefront. Configuration modules gather settings into logical groups for a simpler admin experience.

REQUIRED EDITIONS

Salesforce Compatibility

Salesforce Classic (not available in all orgs) and Lightning Experience for Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions.




B2B Commerce Compatibility

B2B Commerce for Visualforce Winter ’21 (version 4.13)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Spring ’20 (version 4.12)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Summer ’19 (version 4.11)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Spring ’19 (version 4.10)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Summer ’18 (version 4.9)

The configuration information that you manage in CC Admin represents records of several B2B Commerce for Visualforce custom objects:

CC Configuration Module
Defines a logical grouping for individual configuration settings.
CC Configuration Metadata
Defines an individual configuration setting for a module.
CC Configuration
Defines a value for a configuration setting on a specific storefront and page.
Global Configuration Settings

When you first set up B2B Commerce for Visualforce and load global data, the managed package installs a default set of configuration modules and settings. These default settings are global, meaning that they apply to all storefronts you create in the org.

In CC Admin, select Configuration Modules (1) from the Global Settings menu to view the default modules and configuration metadata.

For each module, such as Breadcrumb (2), you can view the following details:

Module API name (3)
A name for programmatically referencing the module and its settings. For example, the Breadcrumb module's API name is bc. Each module API name is unique.
Available configuration settings (4)
A list of default configuration settings available in the module. Some modules define only one configuration setting, and others define several. For example, the Breadcrumb module contains only one setting by default, Enabled, but the Product List module contains almost thirty settings.

For each configuration setting available in the module, you can view the following details:

Configuration Name (5)
An internal display name for the configuration setting, such as Enabled.
Configuration API Name (6)
A name for programmatically referencing the configuration setting. For example, the API name for the Enabled setting is enabled.

Each configuration setting's API name is unique among all settings that belong to the same module. A configuration setting's API name can duplicate another configuration setting's API name as long as each setting belongs to a different module. For example, the Enabled configuration exists in the Breadcrumb, Header, Promotion, and many other modules. Each module can contain only one configuration with the API name enabled, but a configuration with the API name enabled can exist in multiple modules.

The B2B Commerce for Visualforce managed package—including APIs and other utility classes—reference configuration settings by both module API name and configuration API name, such as bc.enabled. Because the module's API name is unique, the moduleAPIName.configurationAPIName convention ensures that the referenced configuration setting is specific.

Externally Safe (7)
Whether the configuration is safe to export to a system outside of the B2B Commerce for Visualforce managed package. For example, a configuration for showing the cart total price in the Header component is probably externally safe. But, a configuration that stores a credential for another system probably isn't externally safe.
Description (8)
Configuration description that's visible as a tooltip in CC Admin global and storefront configuration settings.

In CC Admin, select Configuration Settings (9) from the Global Settings menu to view the default global configuration setting values.

When you select a module, such as Breadcrumb (10), you can view the following details for each configuration included in the module:

Configuration Name (11)
The configuration setting name as defined in the configuration metadata (5), such as Enabled.
Storefront (12)
The storefront that the configuration applies to. All global default configuration values specify Global.
Page (13)
The page that the configuration applies to.
Value (14)
The value of the configuration to apply as the default to all storefronts.
Storefront Configuration Settings

You can override a global default configuration setting and specify a unique behavior for a particular storefront. In CC Admin, select your storefront (1). From the Storefront Settings menu, select Configuration Settings (2). Select a module (3), and then click Override (4). In the New Page Setting window, you can specify a new value for the setting that applies only to the selected storefront.

TIP For information about why and how you can change specific configuration settings, check out the list of configuration settings.
Pages in Configuration Settings

By default, some configuration settings are valid only for a specific page. For example, settings in the Product List module only apply to behavior for the Product List page. When a setting of the Product List module specifies a page of all, the setting still applies only to the Product List page.

Other configuration settings apply to multiple pages, but not all possible pages. For example, the Enabled setting of the Category Tree module can apply to the Home, Product List, Product Detail, Shopping Cart, or My Account page. When the Enabled setting's page is all, the Category Tree widget appears on all of those pages. But, the Category Tree widget doesn't appear on pages where the widget isn't valid, such as the Site Register page.

You can enable a configuration setting for some supported pages and disable the setting for other pages. Click New  and specify multiple instances of the configuration, where each instance specifies a setting for a particular page and storefront. For example, to disable the Category Tree widget on the My Account page but show it on all other supported pages, create two settings:

The Enabled setting has the value TRUE and the page is all.
The Enabled setting has the value FALSE and the page is ma.
TIP For page names, use the page keys defined in CC Admin Global Settings.

Other configuration settings specify storefront information—such as the Image Static Resource settings of the User Interface module—and don't apply to page behavior. Because these settings still require a Page value, use all.

Configuration Cache

B2B Commerce for Visualforce caches all configuration data for loading storefront pages more efficiently. Whenever you update configuration settings, make sure that your storefronts reflect your most recent changes by rebuilding the configuration cache.

List of Configuration Modules and Settings
B2B Commerce for Visualforce defines a default set of configuration modules, metadata, and settings values. To help you understand what specific behavior or experience each setting controls, review the list of settings and check out the help available for each setting. If you're creating subscriber code that references a particular configuration setting, use the appropriate configuration API name from the list.
Build, Activate, or Deactivate a Configuration Cache
Build and activate a new configuration cache, which is a collection of indexed configuration settings, whenever you change global or storefront configuration settings. B2B Commerce for Visualforce uses the most recent, active cache to quickly access configuration data when loading storefront pages. Each configuration cache includes settings for all of your storefronts, even though you often manage configuration settings at the storefront level. You can also deactivate, reactivate, and remove old configuration caches.
Migrate Configuration Data Between Orgs
Most B2B Commerce solutions rely on multiple orgs for developing, testing, debugging, and deploying their storefronts. Generally, you want to propagate the same configuration settings from one org (such as a sandbox org) to another (such as a production org). You can export configuration records and use the Data Loader client application to upsert the records in a new org.
SEE ALSO
